children.title: Alarm signal received (NFPA 72 26.2.2.1(1))
children.hint: NFPA 72 26.2.2.1(1) Alarm signal verification is required by the responsible fire department for a specific protected premises.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Alarm signal time (secs) to receive signal. (NFPA 72 26.2.2.1(4))
children.hint: NFPA 72 26.2.2.1(4) The verification process does not take longer than 90 seconds from the time the alarm signal is received at the supervising station until the time that retransmission of the verified alarm signal is initiated.

children.title: Alarm restoral time. (NFPA 72 26.2.4.1)
children.hint: NFPA 72 26.2.4.1 All supervising station fire alarm systems shall be programmed to report restoral signals to the supervising station of all alarm, supervisory, and trouble signals upon restoration of the activation.

children.title: Trouble signal received (NFPA 72 26.2.2.1(1))
children.hint: NFPA 72 26.2.2.1(1) Alarm signal verification is required by the responsible fire department for a specific protected premises.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Trouble signal time (secs) to receive signal. (NFPA 72 26.2.2.1(4))
children.hint: NFPA 72 26.2.2.1(4) The verification process does not take longer than 90 seconds from the time the alarm signal is received at the supervising station until the time that retransmission of the verified alarm signal is initiated.

children.title: Trouble restoral time. (NFPA 72 26.2.4.1)
children.hint: NFPA 72 26.2.4.1 All supervising station fire alarm systems shall be programmed to report restoral signals to the supervising station of all alarm, supervisory, and trouble signals upon restoration of the activation.

children.title: Supervisory signal received (NFPA 72 26.2.2.1(1))
children.hint: NFPA 72 26.2.2.1(1) Alarm signal verification is required by the responsible fire department for a specific protected premises. TYLA TYLA

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Supervisory signal time (secs) to receive signal. (NFPA 72 26.2.2.1(4))
children.hint: NFPA 72 26.2.2.1(4) The verification process does not take longer than 90 seconds from the time the alarm signal is received at the supervising station until the time that retransmission of the verified alarm signal is initiated.

children.title: Supervisory restoral time. (NFPA 72 26.2.4.1)
children.hint: NFPA 72 26.2.4.1 All supervising station fire alarm systems shall be programmed to report restoral signals to the supervising station of all alarm, supervisory, and trouble signals upon restoration of the activation.

children.title: Occupancy classification, hazard & size of hazard area without changes since last inspection.
children.hint: Select type of communicator device

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Hazard area exit routes are clear.
children.hint: 4.3.5 Suitable safeguards shall be provided to ensure prompt evacuation of, and prevent entry into, hazardous atmospheres and to provide means for prompt rescue of any trapped personnel. A.4.3.5 The steps and safeguards necessary to prevent injury or death to personnel in areas whose atmospheres will be made hazardous by the discharge or thermal decomposition of clean agents can include the following: (1)Provision of adequate aisleways and routes of exit and procedures to keep them clear at all times.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Warning and instruction signs in place.
children.hint: 4.3.8 Warning and instruction signs shall be provided at the following locations: (1)Entrances to protected areas (2)Inside protected areas (3)Outside each entrance to cylinder storage rooms. 4.3.8.1 Warning and safety instruction signs shall be located such that they will be visible to personnel in the area.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
As-Built Drawings On Site
children.hint: 6.12.7 An “as-built” instruction and maintenance manual thatincludes a full sequence of operations and a full set of drawings and calculations shall be maintained on site.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Enclosure without changes in barrier integrity.
children.hint: 11.4.5.1 The protected enclosure shall be inspected annually or monitored by a documented administrative program for changes in barrier integrity or enclosure dimensions.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Room temperature in fahrenheit.
children.hint: 5.1.4.1 Agent shall be stored in containers designed to hold that specific agent at ambient temperatures. 5.1.4.1.1 Inert gas agent containers shall be charged to the pressure, corrected for temperature, specified in the manufacturer’s listed manual. 5.1.4.1.2 Halocarbon agent containers shall be charged to a fill density and super pressurization level, corrected for temperature, within the range specified in the manufacturer’s listed manual. (See Annex F.)

children.title: System appears to be without damage or condition preventing operation.
children.hint: 11.2.2 At a minimum, the inspection shall include verification of the following, as applicable: (3)System shows no physical damage or condition that could prevent operation.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Pressure gauges in operable range.
children.hint: 11.2.2 At a minimum, the inspection shall include verification of the following, as applicable: (4)Pressure gauges are in the operable range.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Discharge nozzles in proper orientation, mounting brackets securely fastened.
children.hint: 10.4.7 The discharge nozzle shall be oriented in accordance with the nozzle listing. 10.4.9 The discharge nozzles, piping, and mounting brackets shall be installed in such a manner that they will not potentially cause injury to personnel.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Piping joints, supports and discharge nozzles securely fastened.
children.hint: 10.4.4 Piping joints, discharge nozzles, and piping supports shall be securely fastened to prevent unwanted vertical or lateral movement during discharge.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Main/reserve Switch Installed properly, accessible and clearly identified.
children.hint: 10.6.13.1 For systems with a main/reserve capability, the main/reserve switch shall be installed in accordance with the system manufacturer’s design, installation, and maintenance manual and the system drawings. 7.6.13.2 If installed, the main/reserve switch shall be identified.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Disconnect switch installed and functions properly.
children.hint: 9.8.1 To avoid unwanted discharge of an electrically actuated clean agent system, a supervised disconnect switch shall be provided.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Actuator last replacement date. (installation date if not replaced)
children.hint: Actuator replacement within date range?

children.title: All hoses for this system without damage?
children.hint: 11.4.4.1 All system hoses shall be examined annually for damage. 11.4.4.2 If visual examination shows any deficiency, the hose shall be immediately replaced or tested as specified in Section 11.7.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Hydrostatic test for Hoses.
children.hint: 11.7.1 All hoses shall be tested or replaced every 5 years. (hydrostatic test)

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
System returned to full operation.
children.hint: 10.7.5.1 When functional testing is completed, the system shall be returned to its fully operational condition.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Overall system condition after test.
children.hint: Does the overall system pass or fail?

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Is suppression system connected to Fire Alarm Control Unit?
children.hint: Select Yes if building has FACU

children.title: System in service at arrival without alarm conditions.
children.hint: 11.2.2 At a minimum, the inspection shall include verification of the following, as applicable: (1) Releasing panel is powered and is free of supervisory, trouble, or alarm conditions.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Panel readily accessible
children.hint: 4.3.8 Warning and instruction signs shall be provided at the following locations: (1)Entrances to protected areas (2)Inside protected areas (3)Outside each entrance to cylinder storage rooms. 4.3.8.1 Warning and safety instruction signs shall be located such that they will be visible to personnel in the area.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Lamps/LEDs function properly.
children.hint: NFPA 72 2022 Table 14.4.3.2(2(4)) Illuminate lamps and LEDs.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Ground fault monitoring circuit operates properly.
children.hint: NFPA 72 2022 Table 14.4.3.2(3(3)) If the system has a ground detection feature, verify the occurrence of ground-fault indication whenever any installation conductor is grounded.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Disconnect switches operating properly.
children.hint: NFPA 72 Table 14.4.3.2(3b) If control unit has disconnect or isolating switches, verify performance of intended function of each switch. Verify receipt of trouble signal when a supervised function is disconnected.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Power supply supervison operating properly.
children.hint: NFPA 72 2022 Table 14.4.3.2(2(1)) Verify correct receipt of alarm, supervisory, and trouble signals (inputs); operation of evacuation signals and auxiliary functions (outputs)'; circuit supervision, including detection of open circuits and ground faults; and power supply supervision for detection of loss of ac power and disconnection of secondary batteries.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Batteries installed and operating properly.
children.hint: Ensure batteries are installed with connection tight and without damage.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Visual Inspection
children.hint: NFPA 72 2022 Table (14.3.1.9(1(a))) Verify tightness of battery connections. Inspect terminals for corrosion, excessive container/cover distortion, cracks in cell/unit or leakage of electrolyte. Replace any battery cell/unit if corrosion, distortion, or leakage is observed.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Temperature Test
children.hint: NFPA 72 2022 Table 14.4.3.2.9(1)  Upon initially opening the cabinet door, measure and record the temperature of each battery cell/unit at the negative terminal with an infrared thermometer.  Replace any battery cell/unit if the temperature is greater than 18 F(10 C)

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Charger test - voltage - #1
children.hint: NFPA 72 2022 Table 14.4.3.2(9(2)) With the battery fully charged and connected to the charger, measure the voltage across the battery with a voltmeter. Verify the voltage is within the battery/alarm equipment manufacturer’s recommendations. If the voltage is outside of the specified limits, either adjust the charger to within limits or replace the charger. (e If the charger is adjustable, adjust the output voltage to 2.265 volts per cell ±0.015 volts at 77°F (25°C) or as specified by the alarm equipment manufacturer.)

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Test results voltage #1
children.hint: enter test results

children.title: Charger test - voltage - #2
children.hint: 11.4.5.1 The protected enclosure shall be inspected annually or monitored by a documented administrative program for changes in barrier integrity or enclosure dimensions.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Test results voltage #2
children.hint: enter test results

children.title: Load test - Amp hours #1
children.hint: NFPA 72  Table 14.4.3.2(9(5))  With the battery charger disconnected, load test the batteries following the manufacturer’s recommendations. Verify the voltage level does not fall below the levels specified. Load testing can be by means of an artificial load equal to the full fire alarm load connected to the battery. Verify the battery does not fall below 2.05 volts per cell under load.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Test results amp hours #1
children.hint: enter test results

children.title: Load test - Amp hours #2
children.hint: NFPA 72  Table 14.4.3.2(9(5))  With the battery charger disconnected, load test the batteries following the manufacturer’s recommendations. Verify the voltage level does not fall below the levels specified. Load testing can be by means of an artificial load equal to the full fire alarm load connected to the battery. Verify the battery does not fall below 2.05 volts per cell under load.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Test results amp hours #2
children.hint: enter test results

children.title: Net Weight of Agent
children.hint: 11.3.7 The following information shall be recorded on a tag attached to the container: (4)Gross weight of the container and net weight of agent (halocarbon clean agents only)

children.title: Pressure
children.hint: 11.3.7 The following information shall be recorded on a tag attached to the container: (5)Container pressure and temperature (halocarbon clean agents with a gauge and inert gas clean agents)

children.title: Temperature
children.hint: 11.3.7  The following information shall be recorded on a tag attached to the container:  (5)Container pressure and temperature (halocarbon clean agents with a gauge and inert gas clean agents)

children.title: Agent Quantity within required limits.
children.hint: 11.3.1 For halocarbon clean agents with a means of pressure indication, if a container shows a loss in agent quantity of more than 5 percent or a loss in pressure (adjusted for temperature) of more than 10 percent, it shall be refilled or replaced.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
External visual inspection.
children.hint: 11.6.1 U.S. Department of Transportation (DOT), Canadian Transport Commission (CTC), or similar design clean agent containers shall not be recharged without retesting if the requalification period specified by the regulating authority for the container has elapsed since the date of the last test and inspection.   11.6.2 Containers continuously in service without need for refill or repair shall be given a complete external visual inspection every 5 years, or more frequently if required.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Record tag attached to cylinder.
children.hint: 11.3.7  Record tag must be attached to cylinder

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Visual Inspection  (NFPA 72  Table 14.3.1(17(2(a)))
children.hint: NFPA 72 Table 14.3.1(17(2(a))) Verify that detector is rigidly mounted. Confirm that no penetrations in a return air duct exist in the vicinity of the detector. Confirm the detector is installed so as to sample the airstream at the proper location in the duct.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Functional Test (NFPA 72 Table 14.4.3.2(17(7(e)))
children.hint: (NFPA 72 Table 14.4.3.2(17(7(e))) In addition to the testing required in Table 14.4.3.2(17)(7)(a) and Table 14.4.3.2(17)(8), test duct smoke detectors that use sampling tubes to ensure that they will properly sample the airstream in the duct using a method acceptable to the manufacturer or in accordance with their published instructions.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Differential Test  (NFPA 72 Table 14.4.3.2(17(7(a)))
children.hint: (NFPA 72 Table 14.4.3.2(17(7(a))) Test smoke detectors in place to ensure smoke entry into the sensing chamber and an alarm response. Use smoke or a listed and labeled productacceptable to the manufacturer or in accordance with their published instructions. Other methods listed in the manufacturer's published instructions that ensure smoke entry from the protected area, through the vents, into the sensing chamber can be used.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Visual Inspection  (NFPA 72  Table 14.3.1(17(6)))
children.hint: "Table 14.3.1(7(6)) Verify location and condition "

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Functional Test  (NFPA Table 14.4.3.2(17(4)))
children.hint: Table 14.4.3.2(17(4)))  Conduct functional tests according to manufacturer’s published instructions.  Do not test nonrestorable heat detectors with heat

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Visual Inspection (Table 14.3.1(17(7))
children.hint: (NFPA 72 Table 14.3.1(17(7)) Verify no point requiring detection is obstructed or outside the detector's field of view

Functional Test (Table 14.4.3.2 (17(6))
children.hint: (NFPA 72 Table 14.4.3.2(17(6)) Test flame detectors and spark/ember detectors in accordance with the manufacturer’s published instructions to determine that each detector is operative.

children.hint: (NFPA 72 Table 14.3.1(17(6)) Verify location and condition

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Functional Test (Table 14.4.3.2 (17(3))
children.hint: (NFPA 72 Table 14.4.3.2(17(3)) Test fire–gas detectors and other fire detectors as prescribed by the manufacturer and as necessary for the application.

children.hint: (NFPA 72 Table 14.3.1(17(6)) Verify location and condition

children.hint: (NFPA 72 Table 14.4.3.2(17(6)) Test flame detectors and spark/ember detectors in accordance with the manufacturer’s published instructions to determine that each detector is operative.

children.hint: (NFPA 72 Table 14.3.1(17(7))) Verify no point requiring detection is obstructed or outside the detector’s field of view.

children.hint: (NFPA 72 Table 14.4.3.2(17(6))) Test flame detectors and spark/ember detectors in accordance with the manufacturer’s published instructions to determine that each detector is operative.

children.hint: (NFPA 72 Table 14.3.1(17(7))) Verify no point requiring detection is obstructed or outside the detector’s field of view.

Functional Test (Table 14.4.3.2 (17(6))
children.hint: (NFPA 72 Table 14.4.3.2(17(6))) Test flame detectors and spark/ember detectors in accordance with the manufacturer’s published instructions to determine that each detector is operative.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Visual Inspection (NFPA 72 Table 14.3.1(17i))
children.hint: (NFPA 72 Table 14.3.1(17(9)) Verify location and condition

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Functional Test (NFPA 72 Table 14.4.3.2(17(8))
children.hint: (NFPA 72 Table 14.4.3.2(17(8)) Test smoke detectors in place to ensure smoke entry into the sensing chamber and an alarm response. Use smoke or a listed and labeled product acceptable to the manufacturer or in accordance with their published instructions. Other methods listed in the manufacturer’s published instructions that ensure smoke entry from the protected area, through the vents, into the sensing chamber can be used.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Visual Inspection (Table 14.3.1(17(10))
children.hint: (NFPA 72 Table 14.3.1(17(10)) Verify no point requiring detection is obstructed or outside the detector's field of view

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Functional Test (NFPA 72 Table 14.4.3.2(17(7(f)))
children.hint: (NFPA 72 Table 14.4.3.2(17(7(f))) Test the detector by introducing smoke, other aerosol, or an optical filter into the beam path.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Sensitivity Test (NFPA 72 Table 14.4.3.2(17(8)))
children.hint: Table 14.4.3(17(8))  Perform any of the following tests to ensure that each smoke detector is within its listed and marked sensitivity range:  (1) Calibrated test method  (2) Manufacturer’s calibrated sensitivity test instrument   (3) Listed control equipment arranged for the purpose   (4) Smoke detector/control unit arrangement whereby the detector causes a signal at the control unit when its sensitivity is outside its listed sensitivity range   (5) Other calibrated sensitivity test method approved by the authority having jurisdiction

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Visual Inspection (NFPA 72 Table 14.3.1(17(1))
children.hint: (NFPA 72 Table 14.3.1(17(1)) Verify that in-line filters, if any, are clean.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Functional Test (NFPA 72 Table 14.4.3.2(17(7(d)))
children.hint: (NFPA 72 Table 14.4.3.2(17(7(d))) Test with smoke or a listed and labeled product acceptable to the manufacturer or in accordance with their published instructions. In theabsence of an automatic, listed airflow supervision feature, test from the end sampling port or point on each pipe run and verify airflow through all other ports or points.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Sensitivity Test (NFPA 72 Table 14.4.3.2(17(8)))
children.hint: (NFPA 72 Table 14.4.3.2(17(7(d))) Test with smoke or a listed and labeled product acceptable to the manufacturer or in accordance with their published instructions. In theabsence of an automatic, listed airflow supervision feature, test from the end sampling port or point on each pipe run and verify airflow through all other ports or points.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Visual Inspection  (Table 14.3.1(17(9))
children.hint: (NFPA 72 Table 14.3.1(17(9)) Verify location and condition

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Functional Test Table 14.4.3.2(17(8)) & (17(9)(a))
children.hint: (NFPA 72 Table 14.4.3.2(17(8)) & (17(9)(a)) Test smoke detectors in place to ensure smoke entry into the sensing chamber and an alarm response. Use smoke or a listed and labeled product acceptable to the manufacturer or in accordance with their published instructions. Other methods listed in the manufacturer’s published instructions that ensure smoke entry from the protected area, through the vents, into the sensing chamber can be used. (17(9)(a)) Carbon monoxide detectors/carbon monoxide alarms connected to protected premises systems (a) CO entry test - Test the devices in place to ensure CO entry to the sensing chamber by introduction through the vents, to the sensing chamber of listed and labeled product acceptable to the manufacturer or in accordance with manufacturer’s published instructions.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Audible Circuit - Functional Test Table 14.4.3.2(15(5))
children.hint: NFPA 72 2022 Table 14.4.3.2(15(5)) For periodic testing, test each initiating device circuit, notification appliance circuit, and signaling line circuit for correct indication at the control unit. Confirm all circuits perform as indicated in Sections 23.5, 23.6, and 23.7.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Counting Zone Circuit - Functional Test Table 14.4.3.2(18(8))
children.hint: NFPA 72 2022 Table 14.4.3.2(18(8)) Operate required sensors at a minimum of four locations in circuit. Verify correct sequence with both the first and second detector in alarm.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Cross Zone Detection Circuit - Functional Test Table 14.4.3.2(18(4))
children.hint: NFPA 72 2022 Table 14.4.3.2(18(4)) Operate one sensor or detector on each zone. Verify occurrence of correct sequence with operation of first zone and then with operation of second zone.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Relay Module - Functional Test Table 14.4.3.2(18(9))
children.hint: NFPA 72 2022 Table 14.4.3.2(18(9)) Verify supervision of circuits by creating an open circuit.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Solenoid Release - Functional Test Table 14.4.3.2(18(6)
children.hint: NFPA 72 2022 Table 14.4.3.2(18(6)) Verify operation of solenoid.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Squibb Release - Functional Test Table 14.4.3.2(18(7))
children.hint: NFPA 72 2022 Table 14.4.3.2(18(7)) Use AGI flashbulb or other test light approved by the manufacturer. Verify operation of flashbulb or light.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Visible Circuit - Functional Test Table 14.4.3.2(15(5))
children.hint: NFPA 72 2022 Table 14.4.3.2(15(5)) For periodic testing, test each initiating device circuit, notification appliance circuit, and signaling line circuit for correct indication at the control unit. Confirm all circuits perform as indicated in Sections 23.5, 23.6, and 23.7.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Exhaust Fan Shutdown - Functional Test (Table 14.4.3.2(24))
children.hint: NFPA 72 (Table 14.4.3.2(24)) For initial, reacceptance, and periodic testing, verify emergency control function interface device activation. Where an emergency control functioninterface device is disabled or disconnected during initiating device testing,verify that the disabled or disconnected emergency control function interface device has been properly restored, including electromagnetic devices usedfor door releasing services as part of a fire alarm system.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Fan Shutdown - Functional Test (Table 14.4.3.2(24))
children.hint: NFPA 72 (Table 14.4.3.2(24)) For initial, reacceptance, and periodic testing, verify emergency control function interface device activation. Where an emergency control functioninterface device is disabled or disconnected during initiating device testing,verify that the disabled or disconnected emergency control function interface device has been properly restored, including electromagnetic devices usedfor door releasing services as part of a fire alarm system.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
AHU Shutdown - Functional Test (Table 14.4.3.2(24))
children.hint: NFPA 72 (Table 14.4.3.2(24)) For initial, reacceptance, and periodic testing, verify emergency control function interface device activation. Where an emergency control functioninterface device is disabled or disconnected during initiating device testing,verify that the disabled or disconnected emergency control function interface device has been properly restored, including electromagnetic devices usedfor door releasing services as part of a fire alarm system.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Visual Inspection (NFPA 72 2022 Table 14.3.1(22(1))
children.hint: NFPA 72 2022 Table 14.3.1(22(1) Verify location and condition.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue

children.hint: NFPA 72 2022 Table 14.3.1(22(1) Verify location and condition.

children.hint: NFPA 72 2022 Table 14.3.1(22(1&3)) Verify location and condition.

children.title: Take a picture of the issue
Functional Test (NFPA 72 2022 Table 14.4.3.2(22(1&3))
children.hint: NFPA 72 2022 Table 14.4.3.2(22(1&3)) For periodic testing, verify the operation of the notification appliances; For periodic testing, verify that each appliance flashes. NFPA 12 2022 4.3.6 Visible predischarge alarms shall comply with the following: (1)They shall be visible throughout the protected space. (2)They shall be distinct from the building fire alarm signal and other alarm signals. (3)Visible appliances, except for strobes, shall not be required to be synchronized with each other or with the building fire alarms.

children.hint: NFPA 72 2022 Table 14.4.3.2(22(1&3)) For periodic testing, verify the operation of the notification appliances; For periodic testing, verify that each appliance flashes. NFPA 12 2022 4.3.6 Visible predischarge alarms shall comply with the following: (1)They shall be visible throughout the protected space. (2)They shall be distinct from the building fire alarm signal and other alarm signals. (3)Visible appliances, except for strobes, shall not be required to be synchronized with each other or with the building fire alarms.
